Green’s Identities (3D)

Like Gauss’ theorem, Green’s identities relate surface integrals to volume integrals. However, Green’s identities are concerned with two scalar fields \(u(x,y,z)\) and \(w(x,y,z)\). Two statements of Green’s identities are as follows

\(\qquad\displaystyle \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S (u {\underline abla} w) \cdot \underline{dS} = \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_V \left\{ {\underline abla} u \cdot {\underline abla} w + u {\underline abla}^2 w ight\} \mathrm{d}V\)

and

\(\qquad\displaystyle \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S \left\{ u {\underline abla} w - v {\underline abla} u ight\} \cdot \underline{dS} = \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_V \left\{ u {\underline abla}^2 w - w {\underline abla}^2 u ight\} \mathrm{d}V\)

Proof of Greens' Identities

Green’s identities can be derived from Gauss’ theorem and a vector derivative identity.

A Vector identity states that \({\underline abla} \cdot (\phi \underline{A}) = ({\underline abla} \phi) \cdot \underline{A} + \phi ({\underline abla} \cdot \underline{A})\).

Letting \(\phi = u\) and \(\underline{A} = {\underline abla} w\) in this identity,

\(\qquad\displaystyle {\underline abla} \cdot (u {\underline abla} w) = ({\underline abla} u) \cdot ({\underline abla} w) + u ({\underline abla} \cdot ({\underline abla} w))= ({\underline abla} u) \cdot ({\underline abla} w) + u {\underline abla}^2 w\)

Gauss’ theorem states

\(\qquad\displaystyle \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dS} = \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_V {\underline abla} \cdot \underline{F} \mathrm{d}V\)

Now, letting \(\underline{F} = u {\underline abla} w\),

\( egin{aligned} \displaystyle \qquad \int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S (u {\underline abla} w) \cdot \underline{dS} &= \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_V {\underline abla} \cdot (u {\underline abla} w) \mathrm{d}V \ &= \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_V \left\{ ({\underline abla} u) \cdot ({\underline abla} w) + u {\underline abla}^2 w ight\} \mathrm{d}V \qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\end{aligned}\)

This is Green’s identity [1].

Reversing the roles of \(u\) and \(w\),

\(\qquad\displaystyle \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S (w {\underline abla} u) \cdot \underline{dS} = \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_V \left\{ ({\underline abla} w) \cdot ({\underline abla} u) + w {\underline abla}^2 u ight\} \mathrm{d}V\)

Subtracting the last two equations yields Green’s identity [2].

Key Point

Green's Identities [1]\(\displaystyle \qquad \int \int_S (u {\underline abla} w) \cdot \underline{dS} = \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_V \left\{ {\underline abla} u \cdot {\underline abla} w + u {\underline abla}^2 w ight\} \mathrm{d}V \) [2]\(\displaystyle \qquad \int \displaystyle\int_S \left\{ u {\underline abla} w - v {\underline abla} u ight\} \cdot \underline{dS} = \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_V \left\{ u {\underline abla}^2 w - w {\underline abla}^2 u ight\} \mathrm{d}V \)

Example

Verify Green’s first identity for \(u = (x-x^2)y\), \(w = x y + z^2\) and the unit cube, \(0 \le x \le 1\), \(0 \le y \le 1\), \(0 \le z \le 1\).

Solution

As \(w = x y + z^2\), \({\underline abla} w = y \underline{i} + x \underline{j} + 2z \underline{k}\). Thus \(u {\underline abla} w = (x y - x^2 y)(y \underline{i} + x \underline{j} + 2z \underline{k})\) and the surface integral is of this quantity (scalar product with \(\underline{dS}\)) integrated over the surface of the unit cube.

On the three faces \(x = 0\), \(x = 1\), \(y = 0\), the vector \(u {\underline abla} w = \underline{0}\) and so the contribution to the surface integral is zero.

On the face \(y = 1\), \(u {\underline abla} w = (x - x^2) (\underline{i} + x \underline{j} + 2z \underline{k})\) and \(\underline{dS} = \mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}z\underline{j}\) so \((u {\underline abla} w) \cdot \underline{dS} = (x^2 - x^3)\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}z\) and the contribution to the integral is

\( \qquad \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^1 (x^2 - x^3) \mathrm{d}z \mathrm{d}x = \displaystyle\int_0^1 (x^2 - x^3) \mathrm{d}x = \left[ \dfrac{x^3}{3} - \dfrac{x^4}{4} ight]_0^1 = rac{1}{12}\).

On the face \(z = 0\), \(u {\underline abla} w = (x - x^2) y (y \underline{i} + x \underline{j})\) and \(\underline{dS} = -\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}z\underline{k}\) so \((u {\underline abla} w) \cdot \underline{dS} = 0\) and the contribution to the integral is zero.

On the face \(z = 1\), \(u {\underline abla} w = (x - x^2) y (y\underline{i} + x \underline{j} + 2 \underline{k})\) and \(\underline{dS} = \mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y\underline{k}\) so \((u {\underline abla} w) \cdot \underline{dS} = 2 y (x - x^2)\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y\) and the contribution to the integral is

\(\displaystyle\int_{x=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 2 y (x - x^2) \mathrm{d}y \mathrm{d}x = \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^1 \left[\phantom{\dfrac{1}{1}}\!\!\! y^2 (x - x^2) ight]_{y=0}^1 \mathrm{d}x= \displaystyle\int_0^1 (x - x^2) \mathrm{d}x = rac{1}{6}\).

Thus, \( \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S (u {\underline abla} w) \cdot \underline{dS} = 0 + 0 + 0 + rac{1}{12} + 0 + rac{1}{6} = rac{1}{4} \).

Now evaluate \( \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_V \left\{ {\underline abla} u \cdot {\underline abla} w + u {\underline abla}^2 w ight\} \mathrm{d}V\).

Note that \({\underline abla} u = (1 - 2x) y \underline{i} + (x - x^2) \underline{j}\) and \({\underline abla}^2 w = 2\) so

\(\displaystyle{\underline abla} u \cdot {\underline abla} w + u {\underline abla}^2 w = (1 - 2x) y^2 + (x - x^2) x + 2 (x - x^2) y= x^2 - x^3 + 2 x y - 2 x^2 y + y^2 - 2 x y^2 \)

and the integral

\( egin{align} \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_V \left\{ {\underline abla} u \cdot {\underline abla} w + u {\underline abla}^2 w ight\} \mathrm{d}V &= \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^1 (x^2 - x^3 + 2 x y - 2 x^2 y + y^2 - 2 x y^2) \mathrm{d}x \mathrm{d}y \mathrm{d}z \ &= \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 \left[ \dfrac{x^3}{3} - rac{x^4}{4} + x^2 y - rac{2}{3} x^3 y + x y^2 - x^2 y^2 ight]_{x=0}^1 \mathrm{d}y \mathrm{d}z \ &= \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 ( rac{1}{12} + \dfrac{y}{3} ) \mathrm{d}y \mathrm{d}z = \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^1 \left[ \dfrac{y}{12} + \dfrac{y^2}{6} ight]_{y=0}^1 \mathrm{d}z \ &= \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^1 ( rac{1}{4} ) \mathrm{d}z = \left[ \dfrac{z}{4} ight]_{z=0}^1 = rac{1}{4} \end{align} \)

Hence \( \displaystyle \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S (u {\underline abla} w) \cdot \underline{dS} = \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_V \left[ {\underline abla} u \cdot {\underline abla} w + u {\underline abla}^2 w ight] \mathrm{d}V = rac{1}{4} \) and Green's first identity is verified.
